captions.text:
John: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. I landed
in Addis Ababa after a thirty hour journey,

met up with Bridget from the Gates Foundation,
and drove into the city where I got some desperately

needed and delicious Ethiopian coffee, shopped
for a bit at a local market to get Henry this

Ethiopia soccer jersey, and then went to visit
Yekatit 12 Hospital.

Hank, Ethiopia is one of the poorest countries
in the world. Most people live without electricity

or running water, most fields are tilled by
animal-drawn wooden plows, and the shortage
of basic services can be overwhelming.

For example, the smallest hospital in my hometown
of Indianapolis has eight neonatologists.

In Ethiopia, a nation of ninety million people,
there are seven. One of the first was Doctor
Mulualem Gessesse.

So, to get to the Yekatit 12 neonatal intensive
care unit, you walk on plywood over standing

water that smells of sewage. And then, up
the stairs to the NICU.

Doctor Gessesse and her nurses have to be
very inventive. For instance, they use the

oxygen tanks, that you see here, combined
with tubing and water to create a kind of

C-Pap machine that keeps premature babies'
lungs inflated. They don't have respirators

or real C-Pap machines, which Doctor Gessesse
cites as among her many critical needs.

But still, she's been very successful. In
the past few years, her ward has gone from

treating a couple hundred babies per year
to more than two thousand.

This little girl had to stay in the dark while
being treated.

Dr Gessesse: We suspect tetanus because she
has spasms.

I asked Doctor Gessesse several times about
her choice of specialty.
Dr Gessesse: So that we continue 24 hours.

John: [speaking to Dr. Gessesse] So why do
you choose to do this then?
Eventually she answered me.

Dr. Gessesse: My concern is for the Ethiopian
newborns.

John: Hank, twenty years ago, more than fifteen
percent of children who were born in Ethiopia

died before the age of five.
Today, it's less than seven percent. Child

mortality is falling faster in Ethiopia than
in the world overall, and it's much lower
than it is in far richer countries.

How has this happened? Well, I'm obviously
no expert, but one, Ethiopia is serious about

health, and two, organizations like the Gates
foundation and Save the Children are helping

Ethiopians execute an Ethiopian health strategy
rather than trying to impose a strategy upon
them.

Like, take Kangaroo Mother Care. When preterm
babies are well enough, they live in the hospital

for weeks or months with their moms, getting
constant skin-to-skin contact. The babies

and moms are together in the hospital 24/7,
and studies have shown that this leads to

better brain development, lower infection
rates, and better weight gain.

It's cheap, it works, and when you make a
small investment in these babies' lives now,

they have a far better chance of growing up
to have healthy and productive adulthoods.

But Dr. Gessesse also told me stories of failed
outreach, as when a dozen C-Paps arrived from

a charity, all of them adult-sized, and none
of them of use to her. We have to listen to
each other.

Hank, I've found humans to be extraordinarily
generous within their social networks, like

think of how quickly we support friends and
colleagues in need. But lack of access to

like, Tumblr and YouTube makes most people
living in absolute poverty totally voiceless

in our online world, and inevitably we begin
to imagine their problems as others, as things
that don't happen to us.

If OUR kids were dying of malaria and diarrhea,
if dozens of OUR babies were dying for every

one that gets access to a jerry-rigged C-Pap
machine, we wouldn't stand for it! But the

thing is, these ARE our kids. OUR world is
also VERY LITERALLY their world.

Oh, and I did get to hang out with Bill Gates
who is brilliant, and I overcame my tremendous

fear of heights to fly in a helicopter with
him, and I will talk about all that stuff

in the coming weeks. But for now let us just
pause to be grateful to Dr. Gessesse, who

has quietly and unassumingly saved the lives
of thousands of babies. Our babies.

As she told me, I have many children. Only
two biological, but many children. Hank, I'll
see you on Friday.

comments.author: 司此雷

comments.text:
Slowly but surely catching up on Vlogbrothers. This is such a gorgeous 
video.
Thank you both so much for sharing your thoughts with the world. Your 
influence is pretty big now (which is part of the stupid reason why I 
stopped watching), and I just want to thank you for staying true to 
yourselves and to your content and, while this may not be the reason why 
you created vlogbrothers in the first place, thank you for helping millions 
of people, from the impoverished around the world to the privileged like me 
who just need a little help getting through the day sometimes. This helps. 
Immensely.﻿
comments.author: firewordsparkler

comments.text: ethiopian hospital. oh, and bill gates.﻿
comments.author: Roderick Daniels

comments.text:
This is so beautiful. I generally struggle with charity videos because I 
know that there are problems in the world and I know that I should put more 
effort into trying to help just a little bit in the smallest of ways that 
combined with other people's small efforts make a big difference, yet when 
I see these types of videos (or commercials, or whatever) all it really 
does is make me feel really bad, and want to think about something else and 
not get involved, for the simple reason that it makes me feel uncomfortable 
and guilty. And maybe that's an extremely selfish way of responding to 
cries for help, and maybe I'm being a disgusting privileged brat, and maybe 
I should feel ashamed of myself, because it's a really nasty way of not 
contributing even though you can. But I think that the reason I, and many 
others, respond like this, it is *because* we feel like disgusting 
privileged brats, and because we *are* ashamed of ourselves, and shame as a 
general emotion is extremely uninspiring. It's destructive, not creative, 
and it doesn't make you want to do the right thing, it just makes you focus 
on the fact that you're *not* doing the right thing, and hence draw further 
negative conclusions about yourself (or about the world or other people, if 
you feel like pushing the emotion away and blaming it on someone else), and 
none of these things make you feel empowered and happy to help others. It 
also does not make you feel like you, specifically, are the one person who 
should be helping, because it makes you feel like you're worthless at 
helping, and thus the logical conclusion is for you to leave the helping to 
other people, people who are good at it and who aren't disgusting 
privileged brats. 
What I'm trying to say here is:
1) This video really didn't make me feel that way. And that inspired me.
2) The fact that this video didn't make me feel guilty made me make the 
above realizations, which was very nice and relieving. Next time I see 
something that would normally make me feel guilty, I'm going to remember 
this and handle it much better. (because knowledge is empowering, hell to 
the yeahs!)
3) I might actually not be a disgusting privileged brat (although this 
point is up for debate :P )
4) Of course, I might be wrong in my conclusions, or at the very least, 
they may not be true about anyone else's feelings of guilt and shame but my 
own.
5) Thank you for a very nice video. DFTBA!﻿

comments.text:
John, 
Congratulations, you achieved your goal again; you've successfully made at 
least four teenaged girls cry (all at once), along with an English teacher. 
I've been citing your videos for an argumentative paper on why philanthropy 
and poverty matters, and quoting you from these videos has made my paper 
much more deep than I could have made it without. I'm planning on posting 
it on the web when I'm done- you'll like the bibliography (the last ten 
entries are all Vlogbrothers).
Thanks John! ﻿

comments.text:
I kind of shudder to think how they would have handled a baby like my 
daughter who went into tachycardia every time she had more then a few 
moments of skin contact so we had to use just clothing and the heat lamp to 
keep her warm till she gained enough to hold a good temp and she was 34 
weeks and had had Betamethosone so a fairly easy case here in the states. 
It's hard to think that many of those kids who were in the NICU with her 
would have had almost no chance under different circumstances and even 
though I obviously knew, it's hard to see.
So we'll have to remember save the children this Christmas for babies just 
like my Katiebug and all her former NICU roommates.﻿

comments.author: the3sweetest3dreamer

comments.text:
I am genuinely crying right now at the beauty of this video, thank you so 
much John for sharing this story. My family is from Ethiopia and while it's 
been 14 years since I was there myself, my memories are of a terribly poor 
but incredibly beautiful place. My mother has been back twice since then 
and she's always shocked by how much things have changed there since her 
last visit, it's improving so fast! It's crazy to see these hospitals and 
infant wards, especially when I think about how just recently, my mom was 
telling me how her own mother gave birth to all 10 of her children at home 
with only local women to help, and one she even delivered all on her own. 
So while these quick fix machines might not seem like much, they are 
absolutely huge. I'm so happy I watched your 2 videos, again, thank you 
John for sharing this, it was wonderful!﻿
comments.author: the3sweetest3dreamer

+Ashley Rushing for one, please do not assume that because I have lived 
half as long as you that I am not informed about the world or intelligent 
enough to form my own opinions about it. many people live to be 80 or 90 
years old and they never actually take the time to learn anything. two, I 
wasn't trying to educate you about anything. I, too, was voicing an opinion 
which happened to differ from yours. and three, I don't need advice from 
anyone on how to "continue" in a world in which I'm surviving just fine.

I didn't intend for this to turn hostile, and I'm not entirely sure why it 
has. I sincerely wish the best for you and your daughter.﻿

This reminds me of how most Americans didn't seem to really pay much 
attention to Ebola until Americans were infected—until someone "like us" 
was infected.

When will we realize that we are all, in fact, human, and that everyone is, 
to some degree, "like us"? Maybe, if we ever do realize that, people will 
take action to fix things a lot sooner.

Just a thought.﻿

comments.author: FUS RO DAH

comments.text:
I am always very reluctant to watch your videos, although I'm also 
continuously interested in what you have to say (on youtube, tumblr, 
goodreads, FB). I love your narrative style, and I really like you as a 
person. But your videos and stories constantly remind me of how little I do 
to achieve something beautiful in this amazing sort of existence that we 
stumbled into and how I completely lost a sense of purpose and 
concentration during this damned 20's. It tells me that I am an 
unproductive member of the society, and not because I don't work or never 
volunteered or donated money, I did/do all of them, but does it matter if 
my contribution is half-hearted and I have no patience nor ambition for 
real progress? It speaks of how limited I am. It overwhelms me and I even 
though feel great to be a part of this, I mostly feel like an impostor... ﻿

comments.author: Orange Will

comments.text:
I understand her perspective - all of my students are "my children" and 
though it may seem strange to others, I care about them as I would if I had 
biological children and I can't imagine I would be very good at my job if I 
did not care about them as such.  Yes there are painful pitfalls of this 
type of care but I also would not trade this for being detached because 
awesomeness does not exist in a vacuum.  I hope that by giving them this, 
they can extend care to the world around them and be able to support others 
in need.  Thank you John, this video is fantastic and I look forward to 
more of your videos about your trip﻿
